story:
During the Christmas break I had the idea (and I will admit a glass or two had been consumed at the time) that throughout January I would force this mountain of lard that pretends to be a body through a 5km run each day. 

It's not about the time it takes, but whether I am able to do it, having not run anywhere for the last 4 years (last time was a sole 5km park run that destroyed me (I was significantly fitter and about 10kg lighter at the time)), or taken any form of proper exercise during the Covid-19 pandemic. It's about achieving this goal. 

Why Macmillan? Having had a cancer scare myself a few years ago, my mum was diagnosed as having cancer. It took almost a year but she has been given the all clear. Throughout this time Macmillan where there to support her in any way they could, nothing was too much trouble. I want to give something back to them for all they did.

I'm already 8 days in and have included screen shots of the journey so far. It's going to be tough, with a weeping blister on one ankle and an achilles and a groin strain already sustained.

story: After my mum was diagnosed with stage 3 ovarian cancer on Friday 13th December 2013 my whole world changed. It’s a feeling like no other, one that hit me like a brick wall and feeling like a rug has been pulled out from under you. I was in a state of shock let alone what my poor mum was experiencing. It has been a complete rollercoaster  since that day and 7years later she is thankfully she is still here. She sacrifices ALOT to be able to fight cancer. Some days are just plain crap and unfair and then she has good times. But none of this she could do without the amazing efforts within the field of oncology. The support she receives from the wider cancer community I know is a massive help to her. This is why I want to give something back. Most of you who know me know I’m not a big exercise person but 2021 is about challenging myself and if by doing that I can help the cancer community that’s a win win.

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

I'm currently in the process of running seven half marathons in seven days between 4-10 January.

This time last week I had no plans to do this and hadn't trained specially for anything.

Don't get me wrong, I'm a runner but haven't done a marathon in over 20 years and have never done anything as extreme as this.

I started on Monday 4 January with an early morning run to the top of Primrose Hill which went well and I've kept going ever since with a variety of runs around the local area, often late at night when it's been quiet and cold.

On Sunday I'll be doing my seventh half marathon which will see me attempt the 21.1km distance for one final time and take my week's running to a total of almost 150km.

To make sure all this effort is worthwhile, I've decided to raise money for St John Ambulance who are currently training 30,000 volunteers to deliver the long-awaited Covid-19 vaccines which will hopefully get us out of lockdown and back to a more enjoyable way of life.

story:
Kier Group has selected the British Heart Foundation, the biggest independent funder of cardiovascular research in the UK, as its new corporate charity partner. The two-year partnership will help in the charitys aim of increasing awareness of cardiovascular disease, raise £250,000 for vital research in to heart and circulatory conditions as well as train 1,500 Kier colleagues in the lifesaving first aid, CPR.

The British Heart Foundation is funding life saving research to help end heartbreak for the seven million people in the UK living with cardiovascular disease. For over 50 years it has pioneered research that has transformed the lives of people living with heart and circulatory conditions and has been pivotal to offering vital treatments that are changing the fight against heart disease.

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

I'm heartbroken to have had to say good bye to my mum, Pat, on 31st Decmeber 2020. I've been so lucky to have had her for 55 years but I wasn't ready to go it alone yet. She was the matriarch of our family and we are all missing her terribly. 

Mum had 2 mechanical valves for almost 16 years. But her heart was still failing so I'd like to support the British Heart Foundation in her memory, and we do have so many happy memories of fun times together with her. I was blessed to have had such a loving mum. 

Thank you.

story:
I grew up with guide dogs. My Granddad was sadly blinded in an accident which stopped him from pursuing his passion: cycling. While a tragedy, the silver lining was first Jessie, then Rosie, the two guide dogs he handed his trust over to and in return they gave him back his freedom.

I didn't know Jessie but loved Rosie with all my heart, and as an adult now appreciate the incredible job guide dogs, and their trainers do.

Two years ago, my family decided to train a guide dog ourselves (well, my mum and dad whilst I interfered with the training). We were given Des, the best dog in the world.

Due to Covid, we had Des a whole year longer than we expected, but this week was finally time for us to say goodbye and for him to start the next part of his training. We are heartbroken to let him go, but know first hand the freedom he can bring to someone.

In the UK today, almost two million people are living with sight loss and of those, around 180,000 rarely leave their homes alone. Many suffer from depression and struggle with feelings of isolation. 

Guide Dogs is here to help solve this problem. We provide individual support that overcomes the emotional and physical challenges faced by people living with sight loss. We work for a world where people with sight loss are never left out of life. We work for a world where blind people no longer feel invisible, where the quality of their eye sight is genuinely the only difference between them and the rest of society. A world with enough support to make the challenges of sight loss no barrier to fulfilling your needs and dreams. A world where being blind or partially sighted isn't what defines you.

I am running (....and maybe the occasional walk) 874 miles from Land's End to John O'Groats during 2021. I am a new runner, having recently completed the Couch to 5K so this will really be a huge challenge. 

I am taking part in the 'End to End Run' for Cancer Research. I have lost my husband and dear friends to cancer and have family and friends currently battling to beat this disease. My late husband, Craig, died from brain cancer far too young and he is always in my heart and cheering me on. My dear friend Tara lost her battle a year ago against cervical cancer and would probably be saying why do you want to run that blooming far! Far too many brave people are battling daily. Sometimes it's hard to find something you can do for someone to show support so hopefully raising money towards the fight against cancer helps.

Every single penny raised is a step closer to finding a cure for a horrible disease that takes so many lives and leaves others bereft. So every donation is greatly appreciated no matter how small.

Thank you so much

Love Jo x

pageSummary: I am Running 1 mile every hour for 24 hours
pageSummaryWhat: I am Running 1 mile every hour for 24 hours
story:
Our RNLI lifeboats in the South East protect hundreds of communities through our 24-hour search and rescue service. They rely on the safest, most reliable lifeboats and modern stations to launch from. From the stunning Dorset, Sussex and Kent coastlines to the unpredictable tidal Thames, our favourite places in the South east are enjoyed by millions of people from across the country every year. But the water remains an unpredictable environment that can catch people out. People will always need our help and we will always be there to answer that call.Keeping a modern fleet of lifeboats maintained, fuelled and ever ready to go to the rescue from all 31 South East lifeboat stations is expensive and we rely entirely on voluntary donations to ensure this service is maintained. 

This is why I will be taking on an enormous mental challenge and be running 1 mile on the hour every hour for 24 hours. To make it a marathon distance I will run 2 miles for the first 2 hours making this challenge even harder!!  This challenge will not only be physically hard but also mentally, requiring me to stay awake for the majority 24 hours and running at all hours of the day. The fact that I will be running at every hour of the day will represent the fact that the RNLI volunteers will drop everything at any time of day to help those in need. I would really appreciate if you could donate even a couple of quid and if not I would really appreciate it if you shared this fundraising page so I can raise as much as possible for an amazing cause. Thank you so much for any help and I will post updates on this page regularly.

You can also follow my challenge on my Instagram @all_the_stations and my Strava, my name being Charlie Griffith and the profile picture being of a Marmot.

story:
The Ethical Fitness Challenge is a 4 week goal-oriented challenge that combines getting fit with doing good. I am committing to walking daily to raise money for Oxfam GB to help communities deal with the frequent and extreme weather that is destroying homes and wrecking lives. My £100 target could help build toilet and washing facilities for families who have been made homeless, or it could feed a family of six for a month. 

I will of course also improve my own physical fitness and my mental wellbeing too as well as the world around me - so it's a win-win! I will post reg pics from my local daily exercise walks and screenshots of steps covered as proof! 

Climate change is affecting millions of the worlds poorest people, right now. More frequent and extreme weather is destroying homes, and wrecking lives. The people who have done the least to cause the climate emergency are being hit the hardest this is an injustice that can and must be stopped.Oxfam is protecting families forced to flee their homes, supporting those hit by changing weather, making sure children have a chance of a future free from poverty and responding to the deadly threat of coronavirus. Through all of this, Oxfam rely on brilliant supporters like you to make sure their dedicated teams can be where they're needed most. They couldn't do our work without your donations - and with charity shops closed right now cos of lockdown they need all the help they can get. Every donation, no matter how big or small, makes a difference. Please give what you can.

story:
Like lots of children, Alice has really missed time with her grandparents and other family members over the last 9 months. She has therefore decided, to walk to see them - or at least walk the distance from her house in Oxfordshire to their homes. She will first visit her granny in Hampshire and, after brief stops with her uncles and aunt, she will end her walk at her grandparents' house in London. She should cover 85.3 miles. She hopes to complete this distance by 31 March - the date after which she is hoping she will be able to see them all in person again. She will need to walk about one lap of the village each day to complete this.
